ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Obviously, I learned a lot of theorems and the necessary tools to solve questions that concern multivariable calculus. But I think through the rigorous psets, I became a more detail-oriented person where I was able to make fast-calculations and do it very precisely. In this course, there were also times where I had to figure things out by myself, and this helped me become more independent as a student.
Knowledge of calculus in multiple dimensions: 3d surfaces, lines, planes, stoke's theorem, etc.
Multivariable Calculus - including vectors, line integrals, surface integrals, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some Psets were very long and repetitive. I understand that that is how the psets were probably designed, but I think the repetitive questions should have been made optional. Also, I did not like the reverse-classroom concept, where I had to watch many videos and solve a quiz before each class began.

The course was overall well organized and well taught. I think that there was too much variety in what was covered and how thoroughly it was covered between sections. It seemed to me as if being in one section over another could've had a big impact on learning and exam performance. To clarify, the course was taught in sections so I never actually learned from John Hall (the professor "teaching" the course) except in his videos.
The instructor is very nice and patient.
Individual classes were more personal than lectures, but engagement with the material was still difficult.

Weakness: The pre-tests before class did not help.  I did not feel the videos should be mandatory, because the same material was covered in the lecture session.  I did not watch the videos and was completely fine.  That being said, they were probably a good resource for some people.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think I would only recommend this course to another student if the student is ready to commit some time for this class. This class is not an easy class, and the concepts that are taught are taught very quickly, so a lot of preparation as well as review is needed after each class. I think that if a student is good at picturing shapes in 3D and can bear tedious calculations, the student should take this class. If the student did not like math in high school, this may be challenging. However, I believe that any student can succeed in this class as long as they put in the work.
If you need to take multivariable calculus, this is the course. Otherwise, not sure I would take this class just "for fun." Definitely not an easy QR credit.
Yes.  This course taught me what I wanted to know.
